title-group.article-title: Comparison of the osseous characteristics of medial femoral condyle and fibula flaps

contrib-group.aff: Curtis National Hand Center, Union Memorial Hospital, Baltimore, Maryland, USA Email: jameshiggins10@hotmail.

permissions.copyright-holder: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand

body.p: The medial femoral condyle flap has usually been used as a pliable corticoperiosteal wafer in small osseous defects such as scaphoid nonunions. However, recent studies have demonstrated its usefulness as a semi-structural flap, including intermediate corticocancellous segments (Del Piñal et al., 2007; Pelzer et al., 2010), and very large flaps from 5 to 10 cm in length (Gaggl et al., 2008a; 2008b). The successful use of the medial femoral condyle in increasingly larger defects raises the possibility that it might supplant the free fibula vascularized bone donor site for the treatment of intermediate to large osseous defects. We have quantified the osseous characteristics of the medial femoral condyle and fibula and compared them. These data can provide guidelines for harvesting grafts according to the requirements of the osseous reconstruction.

Fifty lower-extremity computed tomography scans from an orthopaedic database were reviewed to quantify the composition of the femur and fibula on axial images. Cortical and cancellous layer measurements were recorded using iSite PACS imaging software (Philips Healthcare, Andover, Massachusetts, USA) at 3 cm, 6 cm, and 10 cm proximal to the knee joint on the femur and at intervals of 4 cm, 6 cm, and 10 cm distal to the joint on the fibula. Our measuring technique was accurate to 0.1 mm.

body.p: The average thickness of the medial cortex of the femur was 1.6 mm, 2.4 mm, and 3.0 mm at 3 cm, 6 cm, and 10 cm proximal to the joint, whereas cancellous thickness declined from 75.5 mm to 43.7 mm and 32.2 mm, respectively. The fibula was more uniform and, therefore, averages were used from all the points measured. The fibula had an average cortical thickness of 2.3 mm and a cancellous thickness of 7.0 mm. The femur cortical-to-cancellous ratio increased from 0.04 to 0.11 and 0.18 at 3 cm, 6 cm, and 10 cm from the joint. The cortical-to-cancellous bone ratio for the fibula was 0.65 (Figure 2).

C = 3 cm proximal to joint line. D = 4 cm distal to joint line. E = 6 cm distal to joint line. F = 10 cm distal to joint line.

body.p: Although the corticocancellous ratio of the medial femoral condyle increases in larger flaps extending to the diaphysis, the cortical bone at 10 cm proximal to the knee joint line remains less stout than the fibular strut. In reconstructions requiring osseous stability from both the bone flap and type of fixation (e.g., lengthy humeral defects), the fibula may provide better structural support. In defects where the length of the deficit or deforming forces require less structural support (e.g., radius, ulna, and tibia with intact ipsilateral fibula) the benefits of greater proportions of vascularized cancellous bone may be desirable if adequate fixation is obtainable.

Additional study is needed to provide guidelines for the selection of these two flaps for medium-sized osseous defects. Although the fibula provides more cortical strength, the need for cortical bone in reconstruction has become less common as the quality, design, and locking fixation of orthopaedic implants have improved. In addition, although the advantage of cancellous bone graft over cortical graft has been demonstrated, the relative advantage of vascularized cancellous flaps over vascularized cortical flaps has not been studied.
